content:
Sure, here are some more examples of provocative questions from the Spark Selling methodology that I haven't provided yet:

1. "What's the real reason you're not achieving the results you want?"
2. "What's the real roadblock preventing you from reaching your goals?"
3. "What's the real challenge you're facing in implementing this solution?"
4. "What's the real risk of not taking advantage of this opportunity?"
5. "What's the real cost of not taking action now?"
6. "What's the real impact on your team if you don't address this issue?"
7. "What's the real potential of this solution if it's implemented correctly?"
8. "What's the real key to success in this project/initiative?"
9. "What's the real reason for the success or failure of similar projects/initiatives in the past?"
10. "What's the real potential benefit of this solution for your customers/end-users?"

These questions are designed to help the salesperson understand the customer's true needs, pain points and objectives, and to provide solutions that align with those needs. They are also meant to help the customer see the potential consequences of not addressing the problem or opportunity and to consider the potential benefits of taking action.
